stories.text:
I was experiencing strange bot-"Banned for spam" events over the last for days on a subreddit with small (18) but very particular membership and viewers in the 100-several hundred range, despite the posts only being submitted on the subreddit itself (the promotion to the subreddit was done mostly off Reddit itself).

I tried explaining the the situation to r/Reddit and they agreed I got caught up in the spam filter incorrectly, but so far I did not get a response about the subreddit itself that was banned as a result of the spam filters.

The content was "let's just say important" for the viewership, which I would consider members of an important community in the real world, and the amount of work that went into it ... let's just say A LOT of work went into it.

Does anybody know anything about or have any experience with restoring both a subreddit AND its contents?

Again, the amount of work that went into it, over a LONG period of time, is incomprehensible and duplicating it from scratch would not be possible.

Any help would be appreciated, please and thank you.
stories.title: Reddit's spam filters incorrectly shadow/subreddit banned me; how to restore sub
Typelevel: The Present, the Past and the Future
The need to reform the National Institutes of Health (NIH) funding process

stories.text:
I'm getting extremely frustrated with the hiring/recruiting process.

I've been using laravel since 2013. I know livewire, react, alpine.js, and vue. I'm not perfect, and sometimes I'm a perfectionist or want to go the extra mile and make sure there are tests written at least for mission-critical bits.

I've also played with Remix.run, Nuxt3, Next.js, go, every python framework, Rails, hasura+vue/react frontends.

My problem is the majority of my work has been freelance, and non-verifiable. I have people I've worked for who can vouch for me, but nobody in a FAANG company. I live in rural Utah and work remotely.

I'm 42, and eventually, I'd like to maybe try DevOps or project (or product) management. I'm just struggling to pay the bills because I'm not the best at finding new clients, and I'd like something with benefits that's sustainable.

I also miss working with a team, so it'd be nice to do that again as I learned a lot more working on a team running scrum, etc...

So should I continue looking for a mid+ level position or just eat my pride and go for a Jr level position -- maybe with a different tech stack even so at least I broaden my skill-set?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is it okay to apply for Jr Level jobs if you strike out at Sr/Mid-level?
